qas.question: How do animals typically use the color green?
Why do most fish, reptiles, amphibians, and birds appear green?

answers.text: reflection of blue light coming through an over-layer of yellow pigment

qas.question: What is a chemical that can cause green hue in birds?
What is a protein that carries copper ions in chelation?
What is the green pigment in bile called?

plausible_answers.text: a reflection of blue light coming through an over-layer of yellow pigment

qas.question: Why do most fish appear blue?
What is the name of the chemical in reptiles that causes them to appear green?
Birds eat what pigment that causes them to look green?
What chemicals have humans used in their camouflage?
What is another name for hemanovadin?

context: Animals typically use the color green as <a0_0>camouflage<a0_0/>, blending in with the chlorophyll green of the surrounding environment. Green animals include, especially, amphibians, reptiles, and some fish, birds and insects. Most fish, reptiles, amphibians, and birds appear green because of <b5_0>a <a1_0>reflection of blue light coming through an over-layer of yellow pigment<b5_0/><a1_0/>. Perception of color can also be affected by the surrounding environment. For example, broadleaf forests typically have a yellow-green light about them as the trees filter the light. <a2_0><b6_0>Turacoverdin<b6_0/><a2_0/> is one chemical which can cause a green hue in birds, especially. Invertebrates such as insects or mollusks often display green colors because of <b7_0>porphyrin<b7_0/> pigments, sometimes caused by diet. This can causes their feces to look green as well. Other chemicals which generally contribute to greenness among organisms are <b8_0>flavins (<b9_0>lychochromes<b9_0/>) and hemanovadin<b8_0/>. Humans have imitated this by wearing green clothing as a camouflage in military and other fields. Substances that may impart a greenish hue to one's skin include <a4_0>biliverdin<a4_0/>, the green pigment in bile, and <a3_0>ceruloplasmin<a3_0/>, a protein that carries copper ions in chelation.
